questions.text: The test shown in the Image is used in the assessment of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Binocular Vision The Worth Four Light Test, also known as the Worth's Four Dot test or W4LT is a clinical test mainly used for assessing a patient's degree of binocular vision and binocular single vision. Binocular vision involves an Image being projected by each eye simultaneously into an area in space and being fused into a single Image. The Worth Four Light Test is also used in the detection of suppression of either the right or left eye . Suppression occurs during binocular vision when the brain does not process the information received from either of the eyes . This is a common adaptation to strabismus, amblyopia and aniseikonia.

Highyeild:

Binocular vision- In view of the distance between the two eyes, it is obvious that the retinal images of both eyes cannot be identical , since each eye regards a slightly different aspect of any object observed. The two images are fused psychologically, and this fusion of the slightly diverse images, combined with other facts derived from experience, enables the person to appreciate the solidity of objects or perceive the sensation of depth or stereopsis. Assessment of binocular vision- Various tests using different mechanisms to identify the image seen by each eye are used to assess the status of binocular vision. Commonly used tests are Bagolini striated glasses , examination with a synoptophore , Worth 4-dot test and tests for stereopsis.

questions.text: The following test is used to diagnose which ocular condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both A & B The Monocular cover-uncover test is the most important test for detecting the presence of manifest strabismus and for differentiating a heterophoria from a heterotropia . As 1 eye is covered , the examiner watches carefully for any movement in the opposite, noncovered eye ; such movement indicates the presence of a heterotropia . Option: B. With the movement of the noncovered eye assumed to be absent, movement of the covered eye in one direction just after the cover is applied and a movement in the opposite direction (a fusional movement) as the cover is removed indicates a heterophoria that becomes manifest only when binocularity is interrupted. If the patient has a heterophoria , the eyes will be straight before and after the cover-uncover test; the deviation that appears during the test is a result of interruption of binocular vision

Highyeild:

Heterophoria or latent strabismus Heterophoria (latent squint) is defined as a condition in which there is a tendency to misalignment of the visual axes, which is corrected by the fusional capacity . If the latent deviation is one of convergence, the condition is called esophoria , if that of divergence, exophoria , and if vertical, hyperphoria . If the deviation is torsional, the term cyclophoria is applied. Horizontal deviations are the most common due often to overstimulation of convergence with accommodation in hypermetropia (esophoria) or under-stimulation in myopia (exophoria) . Diagnosis: The diagnosis of heterophoria simply depends on abolishing fusion so that, without its control, the eyes assume their position of rest. The most simple is the cover test : When a distant object is regarded, and both eyes are uncovered, there is no deviation. One eye is then covered so that the eyes dissociate and the latent deviation appears. When the screen is removed, this eye moves at once to regain the position of binocular fixation . The other eye reacts similarly, with the deviation in both being the same. Other tests: Maddox rod test. : Maddox wing test( near tropias/ phorias) Treatment The lower degrees of esophoria and exophoria cause no symptoms and need no special treatment . If symptoms are apparent after any error of refraction has been corrected with spectacles , rational treatment of eso- or exophoria consists in exercising the weak muscles against prisms (with the base of the prism in the direction of deviation) or by the use of the synoptophore .

Synoptophore Sensory function tests with synoptophore. Synoptophore (major amblyoscope) consists of two tubes, having a right-angled bend, mounted on a base. Each tube contains a light source for the illumination of slides and a slide carrier at the outer end, a reflecting mirror at the right-angled bend and an eyepiece of +6.5 D at the inner end. The two tubes can be moved separately or together by means of knobs around a semicircular scale. Synoptophore is used for many diagnostic and therapeutic indications in orthoptics. Synoptophore tests for sensory functions include: Estimation of grades of binocular vision . Detection of normal/abnormal retinal correspondence (ARC). It is done by determining the subjective and objective angles of the squint. In normal retinal correspondence, these two angles are equal. In ARC, the objective angle is greater than the subjective angle and the difference between these is called the angle of anomaly. When the angle of anomaly is equal to the objective angle, the ARC is harmonious. In inharmonious ARC the angle of anomaly is smaller than the objective angle.

questions.text: The given image labelled as B is a test for which grade of binocular vision
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fusion Worth has described three grades of binocular single vision, which are best tested with the help of a synoptophore. Grade II-Fusion . It consists of the power to superimpose two incomplete but similar images to form one complete image . The ability of the subject to continue to see one complete picture when his eyes are made to converge or diverge a few degrees, gives the positive and negative fusion range, respectively.

Highyeild:

Grades of Binocular Vision Simultaneous Perception: It consists of the power to see two dissimilar objects simultaneously . It can be demonstrated by presenting separate stimuli to the two eyes, such as a cage picture to one eye and a picture of the parrot to the other eye. If both cage and the bird see at the same time, then simultaneous perception is presen t. Fusion: It implies the ability of two eyes to produce a composite picture from two similar pictures, each of which is incomplete with small detail . For example, there are two rabbits, each lacking a tail or a bunch of flowers. If fusion is present , one rabbit complete with a tail and holding a bunch of flowers will be seen . Stereopsis: It can obtain an impression of depth by the supreme position of two pictures of the same objects, which have been taken at slightly different angles . Stereopsis should not be synonymous with depth perception since depth perception is the distance of the object from each other or the observer. Even a monocular observer is quite capable of judging distance and obtaining an impression of spatial order.

questions.text: The third-year resident was evaluating a case of squint. He was doing a forced duction test. What is the use of this test?

options.label: C
options.text: To measure the angle of deviation

questions.correct_answer: A. To detect ocular muscle palsy
questions.explanation:
Solution:

To detect ocular muscle palsy A Forced duction test (FDT) is done to find out ocular muscle palsy. It is performed to differentiate between the incomitant squint due to paralysis of the extraocular muscle and that due to the mechanical restriction of the ocular movements . Forced duction test: Positive in cases of incomitant squint due to mechanical restriction . Negative in cases of extraocular muscle palsy .

Highyeild:

Forced duction test It is simply an attempt to passively rotate an eyeball to its full extent of movement to judge if the limitation of the full range of eye movement is purely paralytic or whether there is some physical restriction . The test is performed under local anaesthesia but sometimes under general anaesthesia in the case of very young children. The patient is asked to look in the direction in which movement is being tested and the maximum range is noted. The eyeball is then held at the opposite limbus with toothed forceps and rotated maximally further in the same direction. Interpretation: The test is said to be positive if there is a resistance to full passive movement and negative if it is possible to passively rotate the eyeful with the forceps . A negative result on testing forced duction implies a paralytic or innervational squint . A positive forced duction test indicates a restriction due to contracture or fibrosis of the ipsilateral antagonist or an orbital space-occupying lesion preventing full movement.

Explanation for incorrect options: Option: B . To detect ocular muscle spasms - The extraocular muscle function test is performed to evaluate any weakness, or other defect in the extraocular muscles which results in uncontrolled eye movements. The test involves moving the eyes in eight different directions in space to evaluate the proper functioning of the extraocular muscles of the eyes. Option: C. To measure the angle of deviation - The alternate prism cover test (APCT) is the most frequently used method to measure the angle of deviation in patients with strabismus, but it can only be used when both eyes have sufficient vision for fixation. Option: D. To quantify refractive error - Retinoscopy is the standard method to objectively determine the refractive status of the eye. The technique locates the plane conjugate to the retina with accommodation at a minimum.

questions.text: Sheetal brought her 3-year-old son to OPD for evaluation of a case of strabismus in a 3-year-old child. Which of the following tests do you use to assess binocular single vision?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Synoptophore Binocular single vision is tested by a synoptophore. Binocular single vision is the state of simultaneous vision, which is achieved by the coordinated use of both eyes so that separate and slightly dissimilar images arising in each eye are appreciated as a single image by the process of fusion. The synoptophore compensates for the angle of squint and allows stimuli to be presented to both eyes simultaneously. It can thus be used to investigate the potential for binocular function in the presence of a manifest squint and is of particular value in assessing young children (from age 3 years), who generally find the test process enjoyable. It can also detect suppression.

Highyeild:

Uses of synoptophore - Measurements of deviation : Synoptophore measures both objective and subjective angles of squint. All types of heterophorias and heterotopias can be measured accurately with it. Tests for sensory function - These include Estimation of grades of binocular vision: Worth has described three grades of binocular single vision, which are best tested with the help of synoptophore. These are Measurements of stereopsis that is 3rd grade of a binocular single vision. It consists of the ability to perceive the third dimension or depth perception. Measurements of sensory and motor fusion that is 2nd grade of a binocular single vision. Measurements of simultaneous macular perception that is 1st grade of a binocular single vision. Detection of normal (NRC) / abnormal retinal correspondence (ARC) – In normal retinal correspondence (NRC), subjective and objective angles of squint are equal. In ARC, the objective angle is greater than the subjective angle. Measurements of primary and secondary deviations and also deviation of 9 gazes of position . Test to detect suppression . It is a temporary active cortical inhibition of the image of an object formed on the retina of the squinting eye. When the fixating eye is covered, the squinting eye fixes and suppression disappears. This phenomenon is detected by synoptophore test. Measurements of accommodative convergence to accommodation ratio ( AC/A) . Measurements of torsion. Measurement of fusional reserve

questions.text: Shekhar presented to ophthalmology OPD with complaints of crowding of words while reading for long hours. The following test was done and was confirmed that the patient has been diagnosed with the condition labelled as in image B
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Exophoria The given test is a Maddox rod test, and the pattern of the appearance of white light in relation to the red line denotes a case of exophoria. If the patient saw a red line to the left and white light to the right , they are said to have exotropia or exophoria (crossed diplopia) in which base in(BI) prisms of increasing strength are used until the lines are superimposed.

Highyeild:

The Maddox rod test can be used to subjectively detect and measure a latent, manifest, horizontal or vertical strabismus for near and distance. The test is based on the principle of diplopic projection Maddox Rod Test involves the use of a Maddox rod and the Maddox tangent scale. It uses a specially constructed device, consisting of a series of parallel cylinders, that converts a point source of light into a line image . A patient is asked to fix on a point light 6 meters away . The optical properties of the cylinders cause the streak of light to be situated 90° to the orientation of the parallel cylinders. Because fusion is precluded by the Maddox rod, heterophorias, and heterotopias cannot be differentiated . The Maddox rod can be used to test for horizontal and vertical deviations, and when used in conjunction with another Maddox rod, for cyclo-deviations. If the patient saw a red line to the right and white light to the left, they are said to have esotropia or esophoria (uncrossed diplopia) in which base out (BO) prisms of increasing strength are used until the lines are superimposed. If the patient saw a red line to the left and white light to the right, they are said to have exotropia or exophoria (crossed diplopia) in which base in(BI) prisms of increasing strength are used until the lines are superimposed. A) Esodeviation, B) Exodeviation, C) Hypo-deviation, D) Hyper-deviation, E) No deviation

questions.text: A child is brought by his parents to test his stereo acuity. He refuses to wear any glasses to perform any tests. Which of the following tests can be done without using polarised glasses?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lang test This test consists of a random dot stereogram with panographic presentation . The stereoscopic images of a car, a cat and a star embedded in random dots on the test card are seen disparately by each eye through the cylindrical lenses imprinted on the surface lamination of the test. Therefore polarised glasses/red-green glasses are not required for this test, so can be used for kids who refuse to wear glasses .

options.label: C
options.text: Patient has developed an abnormal retinal correspondence

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: C. Patient has developed an abnormal retinal correspondence
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Patient has developed an abnormal retinal correspondence A normal subject would see two streaks of light forming a cross intersecting at the spotlight . Patients with constant tropia having NRC with no suppression will experience diplopia . Those who have harmonious ARC will see a perfect cross like a normal person. The cover test will show the presence of deviation in these patients.

Highyeild:

Principle of Bagolini striated glasses test : The Bagolini striated glass test consists of optically plano lenses with imperceptible parallel scratches that barely blur the environment but produce two perpendicular luminous stripes (right eye stripe of 45° and left eye stripe of 135°) when subjects with normal binocular vision view one light source . The BSGT is used for patients with strabismus to test for suppression, normal retinal correspondence or abnormal retinal correspondence , particularly in cases of manifest strabismus. The Bagolini Striated Glasses Test is the test most likely to allow the demonstration of fusion in patients who fuse intermittently . Harmonious anomalous retinal correspondence is found more frequently when using Bagolini Striated Glasses Test than with the Worth 4 dot test or the synoptophore.

questions.text: What is the fixation pattern of a newborn?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Monocular fixation Bifoveal fixation doesn’t exist at birth since binocular movements are not coordinated . The two eyes move independently of each other. The principal visual direction of the central fovea & the visual directions of the other retinal points relative to the principal direction is innate . Therefore, monocular fixation is present at birth & is poor . At 2-3 weeks of age, the infant begins to make movements of regard. At 4-5 weeks of age, he/she sustains central fixation of large near objects. At 6 weeks, fixation alternates rapidly between the two eyes and a short time later the child fixates binocularly & performs conjugate pursuit movements. Initially, pursuit movements are saccadic in character but become smooth and gliding between 3 & 5 months of age.
